properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Wodonga, Corryong, Bright, Falls Creek, Mt Hotham, Mt Buller and surrounds
properties.webBody:
The Bureau of Meteorology has issued a Severe Weather Warning for people in North East and parts of East Gippsland and West and South Gippsland Forecast Districts.

  • This Advice message is being issued for heavy to locally intense rainfall developing about the northeast during Wednesday. 
  • Weather Situation: A very humid airmass drawn from the tropics will move over Victoria during Wednesday. This airmass will lift ahead of an approaching cold front, resulting in areas of rain with embedded heavy shower and thunderstorm activity.
  • Heavy rainfall which may lead to flash flooding is forecast for parts of the North East and far northern parts of Gippsland from late Wednesday morning. Six-hourly rainfall totals of 50 to 80 mm are likely, with 24-hourly totals of 80 to 120 mm possible.
  • Isolated areas of intense rainfall which may lead to dangerous and life threatening flash flooding may also occur with persistent heavy showers and thunderstorms, with six-hourly totals exceeding 100 mm possible.
  • A separate Severe Thunderstorm Warning will be issued if intense rainfall is detected within the warning area.
  • Conditions are forecast to ease from the west during Wednesday night.
  • Locations which may be affected include Wodonga, Corryong, Bright, Falls Creek, Mt Hotham and Mt Buller.
Stay informed and be aware of potential hazards caused by the severe weather. Hazards include floodwater, debris, damaged buildings and trees down.
What you should do:
  • Park your car undercover and away from trees.
  • Be prepared for flash flooding.
  • Stay inside if conditions outside appear dangerous.
  • Contact family members and neighbours to ensure they are aware of the situation, if safe to do so.
  • When preparing your property, ensure you take appropriate safety precautions and do so well before the severe weather arrives.

If you are camping:
  • Be aware of local conditions. Rivers can rise quickly with little to no warning.
  • Camp on higher ground away from creeks, rivers, streams, and other waterways.

If you are driving:
  • If driving conditions are dangerous, safely pull over away from trees, drains, low lying areas and floodwater.
  • Drive slowly and obey all road signs. Never drive through floodwater.
  • Be aware of road hazards such as mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • For road closure information, check the VicTraffic website, contact your local council or call VicRoads (13 11 70).

You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.

Call Triple Zero (000) in a life threatening emergency. For severe weather related emergency assistance from the SES, phone 132 500.
Impacts in your area:
The potential impacts of severe weather in your area include:
  • Building damage
  • Fallen trees and branches
  • Flash flooding
  • Landslides
  • Overflowing drains and gutters
  • Damage to vehicles
  • Flooding in properties and homes
  • Dangerous road conditions
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 16/01/2024 05:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicstorms)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

- This Advice message is being issued for heavy to locally intense rainfall developing about the northeast during Wednesday.

- Heavy rainfall which may lead to flash flooding is forecast for parts of the North East and far northern parts of Gippsland from late Wednesday morning. Six-hourly rainfall totals of 50 to 80 mm are likely, with 24-hourly totals of 80 to 120 mm possible.
- Isolated areas of intense rainfall which may lead to dangerous and life threatening flash flooding may also occur with persistent heavy showers and thunderstorms, with six-hourly totals exceeding 100 mm possible.
- A separate Severe Thunderstorm Warning will be issued if intense rainfall is detected within the warning area.
- Conditions are forecast to ease from the west during Wednesday night.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This Community Information is being issued for Heathcote Junction, Wandong.

  • There is a grassfire on the eastern side of the Hume Freeway at Wandong.
  • Firefighters are responding to this fire. 
  • Smoke will be visible along the Hume Freeway at Wandong.
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

Unless the situation changes, this will be the last message issued for this fire

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility:
The following service can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Services on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Pyramid Creek downstream of Ghow (Kow) Swamp
properties.webBody:
This Flood Advice is being issued for Pyramid Creek downstream of Ghow (Kow) Swamp.

  • Minor flood impacts are occurring along Pyramid Creek downstream of Ghow (Kow) Swamp.
  • On Monday evening, Goulburn-Murray Water increased flows out of Ghow (Kow) Swamp from 1500ML/day to 2000ML/day to make space for increased inflows from Bullock Creek and to start lowering the swamp level.
  • The releases are not expected to affect downstream landholders and are expected to reduce from Friday morning.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do:
  • Landholders between Ghow (Kow) Swamp and Box Creek are advised to move machinery and cattle to higher ground, and ensure that any privately owned levees are of an adequate standard. 
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater. 
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes. 
  • Stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
For more information on the increased flows from Ghow (Kow) Swamp into Box Creek, contact Goulburn-Murray Water on 1800 013 357.
Impacts in your area:
  • Floodwater will generally be contained within the banks along Pyramid Creek.
  • There may be some locations where floodwater impacts private land adjacent to the creek.
  • Emergency services and contractors have undertaken works to repair a number of priority breaches. Not all breaches will be repaired.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service 

The next update is expected by 19/01/2024 01:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (Vicfloods) 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: the Goulburn River downstream of Shepparton
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the the Goulburn River downstream of Shepparton.

MINOR FLOOD OCCURRING AT MCCOYS BRIDGE

The flood peak along the Goulburn River is currently arriving at McCoys Bridge where minor flooding is occurring.

Moderate to heavy rainfall is forecast across parts of the Goulburn River catchments which may cause renewed river level rises along the Goulburn River and its tributaries. The situation is being closely monitored and revised predictions will be provided if required.

Goulburn River downstream of Shepparton:

Minor flooding is occurring along the Goulburn River downstream of Shepparton.

The Goulburn River at McCoys Bridge is currently at 9.20 metres and rising. The Goulburn River at McCoys Bridge may peak near 9.40 metres during Wednesday. The river level may remain above the minor flood level (9.00 metres) until Friday.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Check out the Shepparton-Mooroopna-Kialla Local Flood Guide for more detailed information  www.ses.vic.gov.au/plan-and-stay-safe/flood-guides/greater-shepparton-city-council 
  •  Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater. Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/ Rising floodwater can be dangerous. 
  • Be aware of water levels rising near you. Farmers should move livestock and machinery to higher ground if still safe to do so.
  • Floodwater is toxic - never play or swim in floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home may occur in some locations. 
  • Floodwater should stay within the river channel until it reaches close to the Murray River. 
  •  Moira Shire have advised local caravan Parks and are in contact with the Barmah Community. 
  •  Main roads and bridges may be closed due to flooding.
Main Road Closures: 

  • McCoys Bridge on the Murray Valley Highway (B400) is currently open with a 40 km/h speed limit in place
  • Yambuna Bridge Road, Kotupna is CLOSED due to flooding between Curr Road and Wakiti Creek Resort (500 Yambuna Bridge Rd)
  • Stewarts Bridge Road, Lower Moira is CLOSED due to flooding between Bangerang Road Echuca Village and Hoopers Road Barmah
  • Check the VicTraffic website traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au for any new road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 17/01/2024 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: the Goulburn River Murchison to Shepparton
properties.webBody:
This is a Final Minor Flood Warning for the Goulburn River Murchison to Shepparton. 

Flooding is no longer expected at Murchison and Shepparton.

Moderate to heavy rainfall is forecast across parts of the Goulburn River catchments which may cause renewed river level rises along the Goulburn River and its tributaries. The situation is being closely monitored and revised predictions will be provided if required.
The threat of flooding is reduced. Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and beware of hazards remaining in the warning area.
What you should do:

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.

If your home or business has been flooded:
  • Check for building damage before you enter.
  • Have all electrical and gas equipment professionally tested before use.
  • Clean and dry out the building as soon as possible.

Call Triple Zero (000) in a life threatening emergency. For emergency assistance from the SES call 132 500.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Damage to roads and buildings caused by flooding may still exist in your area. 
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

This will be the last warning for this flood. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Warning
properties.location: Areas near the Mount Dandenong Tourist Road in Tremont and Ferny Creek
properties.webBody:
This Warning is being issued for areas near the Mount Dandenong Tourist Road in Ferny Creek.

  • A landslide has occurred in the area near the Mount Dandenong Tourist Road in Ferny Creek.
  • Landslide hazard and safety assessments by engineers are ongoing. 
  • Power infrastructure has been repaired.  
  • Removal of the remaining dangerous trees will continue on Tuesday, however no further disruptions to the power network are required 
  • Works to reduce sediment impact on Mt Dandenong Tourist Road will occur on Tuesday
  • An assessment of the Mount Dandenong Tourist Road condition is planned to occur once tree works are complete.
  • Road Opening will occur when conditions are safe for motorists
  • This Warning replaces the Warning issued at 6:00 pm on Monday 14 January 2024.
Stay safe by avoiding damaged buildings, fallen trees and powerlines, blocked or damaged roads. Be aware of other hazards caused by the landslide.
What you should do:
If another landslide occurs, act quickly:
  • If you are outside during a landside, move quickly and keep clear of embankments, trees, powerlines and poles.
  • If you are inside, move to the part of building that is furthest away from the approaching landslide and take shelter under a table or bench.
Avoid the area:
  • Stay away from the impacted area to allow emergency services to help affected communities.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
Driving:
  • Plan your trip in advance - travel may take longer due to closed roads and poor driving conditions.
Impacts in your area:

The landslide has resulted in:
  • The Mount Dandenong Tourist Road is closed between Churchill Drive and Mast Gully Road and may remain closed for some time. For more information on road closures go to www.traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
  • Properties and structures have been impacted.
  • Fallen power lines and power disruptions. 
  • Fallen trees and branches.
  • Dangerous road conditions.
  • Other impacts to essential services including natural gas and water leaks.
  • Exposed asbestos from building materials within the landslide site.
  • Public Transport has been impacted by the landslide. You should check www.ptv.vic.gov.au/live-travel-updates for the latest updates on services.

Emergency works are continuing:
  • Landslide hazard and safety assessments by engineers are ongoing.
  • Power infrastructure has been repaired. 
  • Emergency services have isolated the natural gas leak and made the area safe. 
  • Asbestos removal works are planned to occur over the weekend (Saturday 13 January - Sunday 14 January) to deal with asbestos hazards and further dangerous trees in the landslide site.
  • Removal of the dangerous trees will continue once the asbestos removal has concluded. This will begin again on Monday at this stage.
  • There will be power disruptions during hazardous tree mitigation works. 
  • An assessment of the Mount Dandenong Tourist Road condition is planned to occur once tree works are complete.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 16/01/2024 06:10 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter (#viclandslide).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Murray River downstream of Torrumbarry to Barham
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Murray River downstream of Torrumbarry to Barham.

MINOR FLOODING LIKELY AT BARHAM FROM TUESDAY AFTERNOON AND POSSIBLE AT TORRUMBARRY OVER THE WEEKEND   
  • Recent rainfall over the Campaspe and Goulburn River catchments has resulted in major flooding at Rochester Town (Campaspe River) and minor flooding at Shepparton (Goulburn River).   
  • Floodwaters from the Goulburn and Campaspe River catchments, combined local rainfall runoff and flows in the Murray River are likely to cause minor flooding along the Murray River at Barham from Tuesday afternoon.  Minor flooding is also possibe at Torrumbarry over the weekend.
  • The river level at Echuca is likely to remain below the minor flood level.
  • Floodwaters from the Campaspe River are the main driver of the current river level rises at Echuca, Torrumbarry and Barham.  
  • The flood peak in the Goulburn River is currently arriving at McCoys Bridge and is likely to arrive at Echuca early next week.     
 Murray River downstream of Tocumwal to Barham: 
  • Minor flooding is likely along the Murray River downstream of Tocumwal to Barham.   
  • The Murray River at Echuca is currently at 89.99 mAHD and steady, below the minor flood level. 
  • The Murray River at Echuca is likely to remain below the minor flood level (93.50 mAHD) based on the observed rainfall.   
  • The Murray River at Torrumbarry Weir is currently at 6.34 metres and steady. 
  • The Murray River at Torrumbarry Weir may reach the minor flood level (7.30 metres) over the weekend. Further rises are possible.   
  • The Murray River at Barham is currently at 5.47 metres and rising. The Murray River at Barham is likely to reach the minor flood level (5.50 metres) Tuesday afternoon. Further rises are possible.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • Stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 
  • High river levels adjacent to Gunbower Island are inundating camping areas and affecting access to and via River Track.
  • Roads and visitor sites are temporarily closed until floodwaters recede and sites can be assessed as safe. For more information visit Parks Victoria.
  • Tree-fall may be an ongoing issue with wet soils and strong winds. For safety reasons, do not drive through flood waters or past road closures.
  • Recent rainfall over the Campaspe and Goulburn River catchments resulted in major flooding at Rochester (Campaspe River) and minor flooding at Shepparton (Goulburn River).
  • Floodwaters from the Campaspe River are the main driver of the current river level rises at Echuca, Torrumbarry and Barham.
  • The flood peak in the Goulburn River is currently approaching McCoys Bridge and is likely to arrive at Echuca early next week.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 17/01/2024 05:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • This warning is for communities in Victoria. Floods have different impacts on either side of the Murray River. For information and warnings relevant to NSW, visit www.hazardwatch.gov.au. Always follow advice from your State’s emergency services.
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

Issue Date: Tuesday 16 January 2024, 03:10 pm
Next Update: Wednesday 17 January 2024, 05:00 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/32514/moreinfo


This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Murray River downstream of Torrumbarry to Barham.

MINOR FLOODING LIKELY AT BARHAM FROM TUESDAY AFTERNOON AND POSSIBLE AT TORRUMBARRY OVER THE WEEKEND     
- Recent rainfall over the Campaspe and Goulburn River catchments has resulted in major flooding at Rochester Town (Campaspe River) and minor flooding at Shepparton (Goulburn River).    
- Floodwaters from the Goulburn and Campaspe River catchments, combined local rainfall runoff and flows in the Murray River are likely to cause minor flooding along the Murray River at Barham from Tuesday afternoon.  Minor flooding is also possibe at Torrumbarry over the weekend.
- The river level at Echuca is likely to remain below the minor flood level.
- Floodwaters from the Campaspe River are the main driver of the current river level rises at Echuca, Torrumbarry and Barham.  
- The flood peak in the Goulburn River is currently arriving at McCoys Bridge and is likely to arrive at Echuca  early next week.       
 Murray River downstream of Tocumwal to Barham: 
- Minor flooding is likely along the Murray River downstream of Tocumwal to Barham.    
- The Murray River at Echuca is currently at 89.99 mAHD and steady, below the minor flood level. 
- The Murray River at Echuca is likely to remain below the minor flood level (93.50 mAHD) based on the observed rainfall.    
- The Murray River at Torrumbarry Weir is currently at 6.34 metres and steady. 
- The Murray River at Torrumbarry Weir may reach the minor flood level (7.30  metres) over the weekend. Further rises are possible.    
- The Murray River at Barham is currently at 5.47 metres and rising. The Murray River at Barham is likely to reach the minor flood level (5.50 metres) Tuesday afternoon. Further rises are possible.


Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Murray River downstream of Torrumbarry to Barham

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for water quality at Lake Bolac. 
  • High levels of blue-green algae have been detected in the lake. 
  • The algal bloom is expected to remain until there is significant rainfall to flush the lake or cooler conditions slow the algae. 
  • Regular testing is being conducted to identify new outbreaks or changes that might indicate improved water quality. 
  • This notification will be reviewed weekly and updated as the situation changes.
Warning signs have been installed at the lake.

You should avoid direct contact with affected water in Lake Bolac.

Do not swim in affected areas or use water for cooking, drinking, washing or showering. Boiling the water will not make it safe. 
What you should do:
  • Visit Parks Victoria website (https://www.parks.vic.gov.au/places-to-see/parks/lake-bolac-highway-park) for more information. 
  • Observe information signs posted at the lake.
Protect your health:
  • Direct contact with water affected by blue green algae can cause skin irritation, sore eyes, ears and nose. If swallowed it can cause cramps, nausea and vomiting. 
  • If you do come into contact with affected water, wash your skin immediately in clean cool water. 
  • Boiling affected water does not make it safe to drink. Boiling water bursts the blue green algae cells and releases toxins into the water making it more likely that you will experience symptoms. 
  • If you are experiencing any health issues after contact with affected water seek medical advice from your local doctor or Nurse-On-Call on 1300 60 60 24.
Protect your pets:
  • Pet owners should prevent pets from drinking or having direct contact with contaminated water. 
Agriculture information: 
  • Irrigation water contaminated with blue-green algae should not be spray irrigated on vegetables and fruit, or come in contact with plants being grown for food during processing and packing. 
  • Fruit and vegetables grown in the affected areas are safe to consume if farmers follow recommendations regarding blue-green algae
Impacts in your area:
  • The water is  green as a result of the algae bloom.
Boating and fishing:
  • Boating and fishing is still allowed in these areas, however care needs to be taken.
  • Fish caught from affected areas should be rinsed and cleaned thoroughly in fresh water, and internal organs removed from the fish and discarded before eating. 
  • Do not eat mussels, crayfish or yabbies caught from the affected area. 
This message was issued by Department of Energy, Environment and Climate Action.

The next update is expected by 31/01/2024 04:20 pm or as the situation changes.

Information about blue green algae:
  • For information on blue green algae visit: www2.health.vic.gov.au/public-health/water/blue-green-algae-cyanobac teria.
Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter.
  • Tune into ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
COMMUNITY INFORMATION - BLUE GREEN ALGAE - Stay Informed
Incident Location: Lake Bolac
Issue Date: Friday 05 January 2024, 10:15 am
Next Update: Wednesday 31 January 2024, 04:20 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/31926/moreinfo

This message is being issued for water quality at Lake Bolac. 
- High levels of blue-green algae have been detected in the lake. 
- The algal bloom is expected to remain until there is significant rainfall to flush the lake or cooler conditions slow the algae. 
- Regular testing is being conducted to identify new outbreaks or changes that might indicate improved water quality. 
- This notification will be reviewed weekly and updated as the situation changes. 



Warning signs have been installed at the lake. 
You should avoid direct contact with affected water in Lake Bolac.

Do not swim in affected areas or use water for cooking, drinking, washing or showering. Boiling the water will not make it safe.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This Community Information is being issued for Antwerp, Gerang Gerung .

  • There is a haystack fire at Fire-Antwerp-Woorak Antwerp Rd, Antwerp. 
  • Haystack fires are not likely to spread into grassland but do generate a lot of smoke.
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby roads and communities as firefighters pull apart the hay to extinguish the fire. 
  • Visibility maybe poor on surrounding roads, including the Western Highway near Gerang Gerung.
  • Antwerp Woorak Rd will be closed shortly.
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

Unless the situation changes, this will be the last message issued for this fire.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 

  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to cal VicEmergency
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

This Community Information is being issued for Antwerp, Gerang Gerung .

- There is a haystack fire at Fire-Antwerp-Woorak Antwerp Rd, Antwerp. 
- Haystack fires are not likely to spread into grassland but do generate a lot of smoke.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Loddon River Loddon Weir to Kerang
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Loddon River Loddon Weir to Kerang.

  • Flood Warning Number: 10
MINOR FLOODING CONTINUING AT APPIN SOUTH
  • Minor flooding continues to fall along the Loddon River at Appin South. 
  • At this stage flooding is not expected to extend downstream to Kerang. 
  • Moderate to heavy rainfall is forecast across parts of the Loddon River catchments which may cause renewed river level rises along the Loddon River and its tributaries. The situation is being closely monitored and revised predictions will be provided if required. 
Loddon River Loddon Weir to Kerang:
  • Minor flooding is occurring along the Loddon River at Appin South. 
  • The Loddon River at Appin South peaked at 2.96 metres on Sunday 14 January and is currently at 2.85 metres and falling with minor flooding. The Loddon River at Appin South may fall below the minor flood level (2.80 metres) late Tuesday.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 
  • Don’t swim, drink or wash in stagnant water. Stagnant water can be harmful to your health.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 
  • High river levels and localised flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Mosquitoes will breed in warm stagnant water after flood waters recede. For more information on protecting yourself please visit Better Health: Mosquitoes.
Road closures:
  • Local roads may be closed in and around Skinners Flat, Woosang, Borung, Mysia, Barraport, Appin and Tragowel.
  • Other roads may be closed or impacted by floodwater. For the latest information please check VicRoads - VicTraffic.
  • Never drive through floodwater.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 17/01/2024 01:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
